qas.question: What is a treaty that supplements a previous treaty in international law?
A protocol may either amend a previous treaty or do what?
Do parties to a treaty have an obligation to adopt a later protocol?
What do we sometimes call an agreement that supplements a treaty especially when few parties to the treaty support the protocol?
A protocol may add additional provisions to a treaty or else do what?

context: In international law and international relations, <a0_0>a protocol<a0_0/> is generally a treaty or international agreement that supplements a previous treaty or international agreement. A protocol can <a4_0>amend the previous treaty<a4_0/>, or <a1_0>add additional provisions<a1_0/>. Parties to the earlier agreement are <a2_0>not required<a2_0/> to adopt the protocol. Sometimes this is made clearer by calling it <a3_0>an "optional protocol"<a3_0/>, especially where many parties to the first agreement do not support the protocol.
